metadata.title: Infectious bronchitis virus attaches to lipid rafts and enters cells via clathrin mediated endocytosis

body_text.text: Most viruses take advantage of cellular endocytic pathways to enter their host 60 cells (1, 2). Once internalized, virus particles move through a dynamic network of 61 endocytic vesicles, which undergoes gradual sorting and complex maturation events. 62 Endosome maturation, in turn, triggers conformational changes and dissociation 63 events in the incoming viruses, which ultimately lead to the delivery of the viral 64 genome and associated proteins into the cytoplasm. In general, while non-enveloped 6 (44); however, the endocytic pathway that IBV hijacks is unclear. 135 The early step in the entry process of IBV into target cells is initiated by 136 engagement of the S glycoprotein with the receptor. Here, using several cell lines 137 permissive to IBV Beaudette strain, we report that IBV virion attaches to lipid rafts in 138 the cell surface and the efficient entry of IBV into cells requires the presence of intact 139 lipid rafts. Several pH-dependent endocytic pathways are used by various viruses, including 444 CME, CavME, macropinocytosis, and clathrin/caveolin-independent endocytosis (55).

To identify the endocytic pathway employed by IBV, pharmacological inhibition, 446 siRNA-mediated depletion, and overexpression of dominant negative or constitutive 447 active proteins were carried out to block or strengthen respective endocytic pathway. 448 First, we investigated the effect on IBV entry by diverse pharmacological drugs 449 treatments which have been well known to inhibit CME, CavME, or 450 macropinocytosis. In conclusion, we conduct a systematic study to dissect IBV entry process in 834 susceptible cell lines. The evidence presented here indicates that IBV attaches to lipid 835 rafts, induces actin de-polymerization, internalizes into clathrin coated vesicles via 836 dynamin1 snapping, transports along early/late endosome, and lysosome, finally fuses 837 with late endosome-lysosome membrane, releases genome in to cytoplasm (Fig. 12) . FIGREF0.text: 140 function of key factors in the various endocytic mechanisms using chemical inhibitors, 141 siRNA silence, and overexpression of dominant negative proteins. To achieve a 142 successful tracking of virion attachment, entry, intracellular trafficking, and 143 membrane fusion, octadecyl rhodamine (R18) and 3, 3'-Dihexyloxacarbocyanine 144 Iodide (DiOC) were labeled on viral membrane as fluorescent tags. 145 Immunofluorescence analysis was used to visualize the co-localization or 146 co-trafficking of virus and cellular factors. Our results reveal that IBV is internalized 147 into cells by CME, transports along early endosomes, late endosomes, and fuses with 148 membrane at late endosome-lysosomes. 149 MATERIALS AND METHODS 150 Cells and viruses. Vero cells, Huh7 cells, BHK-21, and DF-1 cells were maintained 151 in Dulbecco's modified Eagle medium (DMEM) with 4500 mg/l glucose, 152 supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) (Hyclone, USA), 100 units/ml 153 penicillin and 100 μg/ml streptomycin (Invitrogen, USA). H1299 cells were 154 maintained in RPMI 1640, supplemented with 10% FBS in the presence of penicillin 155 and streptomycin. Above cells were purchased from ATCC (USA) and cultured at 156 37℃ with 5% CO 2 . hour (h), the unbounded virus was removed and replaced with FBS free DMEM. The 162 virus and cells were incubated at 37℃ until 100% cells were with cytopathic effect 163 (CPE). After freezing and thawing the virus containing liquid for three times, cell 164 debris was removed by centrifugation at 3000×rpm, and supernatant was aliquoted 165 and stored at −80℃ as virus stock. A control of Vero cell lysates from mock-infected 166 cells was prepared in the same manner. The virus yield was assessed by titration on 167 Vero cells in 96-well plates according to the method described by Reed and 168 Muench(45). 169 R18 and R18/DiOC labeling of IBV or VSV. Vero cells were infected with 0.1 170 MOI of virus until 100% cells were with CPE. The cell supernatant was clarified by 171 centrifuged at 4000×g for 15 min. The supernatant was then centrifuged at 5000×g for 172 60 min and concentrated by 100-fold by using Amicon® Ultra-15 Centrifugal Filter 173 Devices (10-kDa cutoff, Merk, Poland) which provided fast ultrafiltration. Mock 174 infected Vero cells culture medium was concentrated in the same manner as control 175 sample in labeling experiment. 176 R18 labeling was prepared as described previously (44): 100 μl of concentrated 177 virus or control sample was incubated with 2.5 μl of 1.7 mM R18 (Molecular Probes, 178 USA) on a rotary shaker for 1 h at room temperature (in the dark). R18/DiOC labeling 179 was prepared as described (46): 100 μl of concentrated virus or control sample was 180 incubated with 3.3 mM DiOC (Molecular Probes, USA) and 6.7 mM R18 mixture 181 (Molecular Probes, USA) with gentle shaking for 1 h at room temperature. After 182 finishing labeling, the virus and dye mixture was re-suspended in 8 ml 183 phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and the excess dye was removed with an Amicon® 184 Ultra-15 Centrifugal Filter Devices (10-kDa cutoff, Merk, Poland) by centrifugation 185 for 60 min. Finally, 100 μl of R18 or R18/DiOC labeled-virus were obtained.

FIGREF2.text: Anti-IBV S and N antibodies were obtained through immunization of rabbits194 with respective antigens. Anti-flotillin-1 (#18634), anti-GFP (#2956), anti-CHC 195 (clathrin heavy chain) (#4769s), anti-Rab5 (#3547s), anti-Rab7 (#9367s), and 196 anti-LAMP1 (#9091s) were purchased from Cell Signaling Technology (USA).197 Anti-VSV G (Ab50549) was obtained from Abcam (UK). Anti-β-actin (A1978) was 198 purchased from Sigma Aldrich (USA). Cholera Toxin Subunit B (CTB, C34775) was 199 purchased from Thermo Fisher Scientific (USA). Fluorescein isothiocyanate 200 (FITC)-conjugated anti-mouse or anti-rabbit immunoglobulin G (IgG), as well as 201 horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-conjugated anti-mouse or antianti-Rabbit IgG (H+L) Highly Cross-Adsorbed Secondary Antibody, Alexa Fluo 204 r 633 (A-21071) was purchased from Thermo fisher(USA) 205 Virus infection and drug treatment. To test the effect of various inhibitors on IBV 206 infection, Vero cells, H1299 cells, BHK-21 cells, or Huh7 cells were seeded into 207 6-well plates at 5×10 6 cells/well and cultured for 24 h until they reached 100% 208 confluence. Cells were then pretreated with the indicated concentrations of NH 4 Cl, 209 CPZ, Nystatin, or Amiloride for 30 min at 37℃, respectively. After treatment, 1 MOI 210 of virus was inoculated into each well and incubated at 4℃ for 1 h in the absence of 211 compounds. The unbound virions were washed away with cold PBS and the cells 212 incubated at 37℃ with respective compounds in fresh medium for 1 h. After that, 213 cells were replenished with fresh medium without compounds. Virus internalization 214 was determined by semi-quantitative real time RT-PCR at 2 h.p.i. by measuring the 215 viral RNA genome, and virus replication was monitored by Western blot at 8 h.p.i. by 216 checking the expression level of viral N protein.217 author/funder. FIGREF3.text: Cholesterol depletion and replenishment. Cells were incubated with 5 mM MβCD 231 for 30 min at 37℃ at indicated infection time course. The cells exposed to DMSO for 232 30 min were set as control group. After incubation, the cells were washed twice with 233 PBS and replaced with fresh culture medium. For cholesterol replenishment, cells 234 were pretreated with 2.5 or 5 mM MβCD for 30 min at 37℃, then supplemented with 235 or without exogenous 1 mM cholesterol and incubated for 1 h at 37℃. After extensive 236 washing with PBS, the cells were subjected to IBV infection.

FIGREF5.text: Plasmid transfection and siRNA transfection. Cells grown in 6-well plates were 249 transfected with 3 µg of plasmid DNA, by using lipofectamine 3000 (Invitrogen) 250 according to the manufacturer's instructions. After 24 h post-transfection, cells were 251 infected with IBV at MOI of 1. The internalization level of IBV genomic RNA was 252 determined by semi-quantitative real time RT-PCR at 2 h.p.i., the levels of viral 253 proteins expression were measured by Western blot analysis at 8 h.p.i., and the virus 254 particle release in the supernatant was assessed by TCID 50 measurement at 12 h.p.i.. 255 To knock down Eps15, dynamin1, Rab5, or Rab7, cells were seeded into 6-well 256 plates, and small interfering RNA (siRNA) duplexes at a concentration of 100 nM 257 were transfected into the cells by using Lipofectamine 3000 according to the 258 manufacturer's instructions. At 36 h post-transfection, cells were infected with IBV at 259 MOI of 1. FIGREF14.text: 345 including viral receptors, are preferentially localized at. Various viruses enter host 346 cells through lipid rafts (26). Previous report showed that IBV structural proteins 347 migrate and integrate into lipid rafts during infection, while non-structural proteins do 348 not integrate into rafts (38), suggesting that lipid rafts might participate in virus entry 349 or budding/release. To examine which stage of infection that lipid rafts are involved in, 350 MβCD was used to disrupt lipid rafts. The subtoxic dose of the MβCD in IBV 351 permissive cell lines was determined by a cell proliferation assay (Supplementary Fig. 352 1). After determination of subtoxic dose, Vero, H1299, Huh7 cells were treated with 5 353 mM MβCD for 30 min at pre-, during-, or post-IBV infection at -0.5, 0, 1, 2 h.p.i. 354 (Fig. 1A). The effect of MβCD on virus infection was accessed by checking viral 355 gRNA, viral protein, and progeny virus with semi-quantitative real time RT-PCR, genome level, which was determined by checking negative stranded genomic 359 RNA at 4 h.p.i.. Surprisingly, treatment with MβCD at 1 and 2 h.p.i. did not affect the 360 virus genome production. Next, viral N protein expression was analyzed with Western 361 blot at 8 h.p.i.. As shown in Fig. 1C, 1F, 1I, treatment with MβCD -1.5 and 0 h.p.i. 362 obtained maximum inhibition effect on viral N protein expression in various cell lines, 363 whereas treatment with MβCD at post-entry step did not affect the viral N protein 364 expression. In consistence, the progeny virus release was also inhibited by MβCD 365 treatment at -1.5 and 0 h.p.i., but not by post-entry treatment (Fig. 1D, 1G, 1J). In all, 366 above data demonstrate that MβCD inhibits virus entry step, but not post-entry 367 process, suggesting that intact lipid rafts are required for virus attachment and/or 368 entry. 369 To confirm whether the effect of the MβCD on virus entry was due to cholesterol 370 depletion, we examined the effect of exogenous cholesterol replenishment on virus 371 entry after MβCD treatment. Vero, H1299, and Huh7 cells were pretreated with 2.5 or 372 5 mM MβCD for 30 min, supplemented with/without exogenous 1 mM cholesterol for 373 1 h, followed with IBV infection. The incoming virus gRNA, the expression of IBV N 374 protein, and the progeny virus particles in the culture medium, were examined. The 375 incoming virus gRNA was examined with semi-quantitative real time RT-PCR at 2 376 h.p.i.. Results in Fig. 2A, 2D, 2G showed that MβCD treatment reduced virus gRNA 377 internalization, however, cholesterol replenishment restored virus entry. Accordingly, 378 virus protein expression was determined with Western blot at 8 h.p.i.. As shown in Fig. 379 2B, 2E, and 2H, compared to that in control treatment cells, viral N protein expression 380 was reduced by MβCD treatment and was restored in cholesterol replenishment cells.

To ensure subtoxic doses of the 417 drug, Vero cells were treated with 0-160 mM NH 4 Cl for 30 min, and cytotoxic effects 418 were evaluated by cell viability assay. As shown in Fig. 4A, Vero cells tolerated the 419 treatment of NH 4 Cl up to 100 mM. Next, acridine orange staining was performed to 420 confirm increasing pH in intercellular vesicles caused by the drug treatment. Results 421 in Fig. 4B showed that untreated cells displayed typical orange fluorescence, 422 indicative of acidic compartments. As expected, the orange fluorescence decreased 423 along with increasing concentration of NH 4 Cl treatment, and 100 mM NH 4 Cl 424 treatment totally quenched the orange fluorescence, confirming pH increased in 425 NH 4 Cl treated cells. To examine the functional role of a low pH on IBV infectivity, 426 we pretreated various cell lines with 0-100 mM NH 4 Cl for 30 min, followed by 427 inoculation with IBV for 1 h at 4℃. The temperature was shifted to 37℃ for an 428 additional 1 h to allow synchronized entry. Internalized virus was quantified by 429 detection of viral gRNA at 2 h.p.i.. As shown in Fig. 4C, 4E, 4G, 4I, virus 430 internalization was significantly reduced by NH 4 Cl pretreatment in a dose-dependent 431 manner, compared to those in H 2 O treated cells. The virus replication upon NH 4 Cl 432 treatment was monitored by detection of viral N protein at 8 h.p.i.. The basic 433 mechanism of pH-dependent endocytosis for VSV has been known for many years 434 and is well documented (51-54). Thus, VSV infection of Vero cells was included in 435 this experiment as a positive control. Western blot result in Fig. 4D showed that VSV 436 G protein expression was decreased by NH 4 Cl treatment in dose dependent manner, 437 suggesting that this drug really inhibited VSV infection. Data in Fig. 4D, 4F, 4H, 4J 438 showed that IBV N protein production was significantly decreased by NH 4 Cl 439 treatment in dose dependent manner. Taken together, these results demonstrate that 440 IBV entry requires low-pH environment in the endosome in various cell lines, 441 consistent with the previous report (44).

To this purpose, cells were transfected with siRNA targeting CHC and then 537 infected with IBV (H1299 cells) or VSV (Vero cells). As shown in Fig. 7H-J, 538 depletion of CHC was accompanied by a significant reduction of IBV gRNA 539 internalization and IBV/VSV protein expression, which further demonstrates a 540 functional clathrin pathway is required for efficient IBV infection. 541 IBV entry leads to active actin rearrangement. 542 In Saccharomyces cerevisae, clathrin-coated patches on the cell surface mature 543 into ∼200 nm tubular invaginations with coat proteins at their tip. The actin 544 cytoskeleton machinery is recruited after coat formation and provides an essential 545 force for membrane deformation and internalization (69). Recent studies have 546 revealed that the rhabdoviruses (70), VSV (7), RABV (71), and IHNV (72) are 547 internalized through CME and depend on actin. Although we have demonstrated that 548 IBV enter cells by hijacking clathrin dependent route, it is unclear whether actin 549 filaments are involved in IBV uptake. To examine the role of actin filaments in IBV 550 entry, we first examined the actin polymerization during IBV internalization. Vero 551 cells were incubated with IBV at 4℃ for 1 h, and the temperature was shifted to 37℃. 552 Actin filaments were stained with Alexa Fluor 488-phalloidin (green) and IBV N 553 antibody at 15 min time interval and were observed by confocal microscopy. In 554 mock-infected cells, the actin stress fibers were visible clearly. At 15 to 45 min.p.i., 555 the number of actin stress fibers dramatically decreased, the cells rounded up, and infection results in transient actin de-polymerization and re-arrangement. 559 IBV N protein antibody is not sensitive enough to detect the incoming virus. To check 560 whether of IBV internalization associates with actin, R18-IBV was applied to Vero 561 cell. Actin filaments were stained with Alexa Fluor 488-phalloidin at 15 min time 562 interval, and the red signal of R18-IBV and green signal of actin were observed. As 563 expected, images in Fig. 8B showed that there was no R18 red signal in mock 564 infection group. In the R18-IBV infection group, R18-IBV was detected at cell 565 surface at 0 min, displayed as red signal. After attachment, R18-IBV entered cells and 566 co-localized well with actin at 15, 30, and 45 min, shown as yellow signal. At 60 min, 567 Most R18-IBV particles separated with actin, displayed as red signal again. This 568 observation suggests that IBV enters cells via actin cytoskeleton. Here, we also 569 incubated the well characterized R18-VSV with Vero cells as control group. As 570 R18-VSV enters into cells quickly, we chose the time interval of 5 min. Image in 571 Supplementary Fig. 2A showed that R18-VSV also caused actin fiber 572 de-polymerization and cell rounded up at 5-30 min.p.i.. The cell morphology and 573 actin distribution returned to normal at 30 min. Meanwhile, R18-VSV co-localized 574well with actin at 5, 10, 20, and 30 min, suggesting that VSV also moves along actin 575 fiber after internalization, consistent with previous report (73).

FIGREF38.text: enter the host cell to start their life cycle. Thus, characterization of 730 viral entry pathway is important for understanding of virus pathogenesis and design of 731 anti-viral drugs. Envelope viruses penetrate cells by two different ways: fusion with 732 cell plasma membrane or receptor-mediated endocytosis. Direct membrane fusion on 733 the cell surface is independent of low pH, and access through the endocytosis pathway 734 usually relies on the low pH of the endocytic vesicles. Different endocytosis pathways 735 have been characterized over the past decade, in which the CME is one of the most 736 commonly used by many envelope viruses (93). Coronavirus entry is mediated by S 737 protein, which is responsible for receptor binding and membrane fusion. Previously, it 738 has been demonstrated that SARS-CoV is internalized by CME in human hepatoma 739 HepG2 cell line (39), however, in HEK293E-ACE2-GFP cells, the entry of 740 SARS-CoV is clathrin-and caveolae-independent (40); MHV entry is mediated by 741 CME through the endo-/lysosomal pathway in proteolysis-dependent manner (43, 742 94-97); PHEV enters into cells via CME in Rab5, cholesterol, and low pH 743 dependent manner (98); HCoV-NL63 requires CME for successful entry into the 744 LLC-MK2 cells (99); for the HCoV-229E, a CavME uptake has been suggested (16), 745 however, the clinical isolates of HCoV-229E bypass the endosome for cell entry (100).746Above evidence demonstrates that coronavirus enter cells via multiple pathways.747Thus, study on IBV entry mechanisms is necessary for understanding group 3 748 coronavirus infection process. As mentioned previously, the infectivity of IBV on 749 BHK cells is inhibited by NH 4 Cl treatment (44), demonstrating that IBV entry 750 requires low pH triggered membrane fusion. In this study, we made an effort to 751 systematically examine every step of this process. First, we found that IBV particles 752 initially attach to lipid rafts on plasma membrane, and enter cells via CME, which 753 requires the help of CHC and dynamin1. Additionally, we demonstrate that IBV 754 particles are transported via early and late endosome, and fuse with late 755 endosome-lysosome membrane to release the nucleocapsid.

FIGREF39.text: are involved in regulation of different biological events, serve as 757 organizing centers of signaling molecules assembly, and influence membrane fluidity 758 and membrane protein trafficking (101). The involvement of lipid rafts in virus entry, 759 assembly and budding has been demonstrated by either the co-localization study of 760 the viral structural proteins and lipid rafts or the effects of lipid rafts disrupting agents 761 on the replication processes of several viruses (102). The best characterized lipid 762 rafts-related non-enveloped viral entry is simian virus 40 (SV40) and echovirus type 1 763 (EV1) (103, 104). Binding of SV40 with MHC class I receptors triggers receptor 764 clustering and redistribution, more caveolae is recruited from the cytoplasm at the site 765 of entry, resulting in caveolae-mediated endocytosis in about 20 min (104). In some 766 cell types, SV40 can enter the caveosomes directly from lipid rafts in non-coated 767 vesicles (105). Similar to SV40, EV1 attachment and binding with cells triggers 768 clustering and relocation of α2β1-integrin receptors from lipid rafts to the 769 caveolae-like structures (104). Depletion of cholesterol in lipid rafts inhibits EV1 770 infection (103). For envelope virus, Semliki Forest virus (SFV) and Sindbis virus 771 (SIN) require cholesterol and sphingolipids in target membrane lipid rafts for 772 envelope glycoprotein-mediated membrane fusion and entry (29). Many envelope 773 virus receptors are located in lipid rafts or would be relocated into lipid rafts after 774 infection, such as Human T-lymphotropic virus Type I (HTLV-1) receptor glucose 775 transporter 1 (GLUT-1), Ebola virus and Marburg virus folate receptor-α (FRα), 776 Hepatitis B virus complement receptor type 2 (CR2), Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) 777 receptor CD46 (106). An alternative receptor for Human Immunodeficiency virus 778 (HIV-1) envelope glycoprotein on epithelial cells is glycosphingolipid 779 galactosyl-ceramide (GalCer), which also enriches at lipid rafts (107, 108). Membrane 780 cholesterol is also involved in the first stages of flavivirus infection (47, 109). Guo et 781 al demonstrate that IBV structural proteins, but not non-structural proteins, migrate 782 and integrate into lipid rafts after viral protein translation. The cholesterol enriched 783 microdomains were only involved in IBV attachment, not virus replication or virus 784 particle release (38). However, the involvement mechanisms of lipid rafts on IBV 785 infectivity are still unclear. In our study, we substantiated the involvement of lipid virus life cycle via disruption of lipid rafts by using chemicals at pre-, during-, 787 or post-infection, and checked IBV internalization, viral protein expression, and 788 progeny virus release. Results showed that lipid rafts were involved in IBV entry step. 789 Cholesterol replenishment experiment further confirmed that lipid rafts were 790 necessary for IBV entry. Membrane flotation assay showed the co-fractionation of 791 IBV particles and lipid rafts during absorption step. Immunofluoresence showed that 792 R18-IBV associates with lipid rafts on the cells surface. Above evidence substantiates 793 that IBV initiates the entry step by attaching to lipid rafts. 794 Further experiment showed that chemical inhibitor of endosome acidification 795 (NH 4 Cl) treatment in various susceptible cells reduced the IBV internalization and 796 protein expression, suggesting a requirement for transport of virions to endosomes. To797

FIGREF40.text: 804 observations, Huh7, a caveolin deficient cell line (110, 111), was used in the 805 cholesterol depletion experiment. When cholesterol was depleted by chemicals or 806 replenished in Huh7 cells, similar inhibition effect on IBV entry was observed as that 807 in Vero and H1299 cells. These results confirm that although IBV attachment and 808 entry depend on the intact lipid rafts, CME is the main endocytotic pathway for 809 internalization.

FIGREF41.text: Our final research question was the virus trafficking route. By using R18-labeled 811 IBV to infect cells, we found that IBV attachment leads to actin rearrangement and 812 co-localized with actin filament after internalization. This indicates that virus 813 internalization requires the actin de-polymerization or polymerization, to facilitate the late endosomes, and ablation of Rab5 and Rab7 has been widely used to 818 study viral entry. Using R18-labeled virus, we found that after internalization,819    incoming IBV particles were first co-localized with Rab5 and then with Rab7, finally 820 overlapped with lysosome marker LAMP1, across the entire endocytic network. The821 importance of Rab proteins were examined by overexpression and RNA interference 822 technology. The results showed that Rab5 and Rab7 played crucial roles for IBV entry, 823 confirming that IBV trafficking really depends on early and late endosomes. Also, 824 using the R18 and DiOC double labeled virus, we revealed that the membrane fusion 825 happens at 2-3 h.p.i., the time point of virus reaches late endosome-lysosome. 826 Overexpression of VCP, a protein involved in endosome maturation, increased virus 827 gene expression. We speculated that IBV particles were first transported to early 828 endosomes in Rab5-demepdent manner, and were guided to late endosomes in Rab7 829 and VCP dependent manner. Also, the Rab7 dependence indicates that membrane 830 fusion depends on endosomal maturation, suggesting that low pH environment in the 831 late endosome-lysosome may provide an important signal for fusion and viral gRNA 832 release.

FIGREF42.text: An understanding of the cellular components involved in IBV invasion into the cell, is839    likely to open new opportunities to develop novel therapeutic approaches.

FIGREF50.text: Model of IBV internalization, trafficking, and fusion. IBV attaches to 1277 lipid rafts on the cell surface and is internalized from the plasma membrane via CME, 1278 with the help of dynamin1 and actin de-polymerization. The virus containing clathrin 1279 coated vesicles were taken up in Rab5-containing early endosomes, transferred into 1280 late endosomes and lysosomes. The low pH environment in late 1281 endosomes-lysosomes induces virus-cell membrane fusion.

TABREF0.text: Measurement of virus genomic RNA (gRNA) by semi-quantitative real timeRT-PCR. Viral internalization was detected as described previously (47). Briefly, the cells in 6-well plates were incubated with IBV (MOI=1) at 4℃ for 1 h. The unbound virions were washed away with cold PBS, and the cells were incubated at 37℃ with fresh medium. At 2 h.p.i., cells were treated with 1 mg/ml proteinase K (Invitrogen)for 15 min to remove adsorbed but not internalized virus. Proteinase K was then inactivated with 2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF) in PBS with 3% bovine serum albumin. Cells were then washed three times with PBS and lysed in 1 ml of TRIZOL reagent (Invitrogen, USA) per well for RNA isolation. One fifth volume of chloroform was added. The mixture was centrifuged at 13,000×rpm for 15 author/funder. All rights reserved.
